cards.desc:
* Plan on **“exploring”** the product at the beginning of each new sprint.
* Plan and build your **scripts** to perform **automated functional** and **regression testing** within the sprint (Because there is not enough time for performing thorough manual testing).
* Use the **sprint backlog** as your own **test plan** 
* Some teams are treating **test case scenarios** as entries that need to be **added to the sprint backlog** for planning and tracking purposes
* **Understand**, **remember**, and **process details**.(Take notes!!!!)
* **Transparency**: Provide **traceability** among **tests**, **features**, **bugs** and **report** my **testing progress**
* **Acceptance Test Log** of the exploratory test run (brief)
* Send a **daily status email** (brief)
cards.name: QA in Scrum

cards.desc:
# Goal:

* Perform machinery test cases in a scripted way (non-interactive)
* Record the terminal sessions. Ability to reproduce them in html.

# Acceptance Criteria:

* You can read the log file of the session
* You can reproduce the session in a browser

data.text:
Features:


* Cli app.
* Test scenarios.
* Run jenkins jobs.

Architecture:

* Python
* DocOpt module (http://docopt.org/)

** Ideas: **

* Central logs in admin node
* Twopence
* Log management app to filter and customize logs

card.name: Don't fetch images that haven't changed

data.text:
* Could also use some "wget -m" of the directory ... simply to not fetch images when they're already there, but look at some http E-TAG / header / whatever [*.sha256]
* When we simply fetch also *.sha256, any call to get-images.sh could fetch *.sha256 and check if the local sum matches the one it already have. when yes, don't download image.

* Result [along with some atomic replace mktemp, link & co ...] would be, that we can create a job that is calling get-images.sh every 10 minutes 
wget -m could perhaps even do this using some http features.

* when not, we can fetch sha files first, and fetch images + packages only when they differ somehow.

* Then put the sut....packages file to artifacts, so we know: this test were using libteam-42.0 with wicked-0.6.28 [e.g. pre-installed in the sut without to build wicked from git or fetch via osc getbinaries] and the other build were using another combination.

* When you build RPMs, put the wicked RPMs + SRCs (src.rpm) to the results too.

card.name: Don't fetch images that haven't changed

* Currently I was faking this by pinging SUT ip address.
* It should ping an ip address from REF.

https://github.com/dblock/jenkins-ansicolor-plugin

card.name: QA in Scrum
card.desc:
* Plan on **“exploring”** the product at the beginning of each new sprint.
* Plan and build your **scripts** to perform **automated functional** and **regression testing** within the sprint (Because there is not enough time for performing thorough manual testing).
* Use the **sprint backlog** as your own **test plan** 
* Some teams are treating **test case scenarios** as entries that need to be **added to the sprint backlog** for planning and tracking purposes
* **Understand**, **remember**, and **process details**.(Take notes!!!!)
* **Transparency**: Provide **traceability** among **tests**, **features**, **bugs** and **report** my **testing progress**
* **Acceptance Test Log** of the exploratory test run (brief)
* Send a **daily status email** (brief)

old.desc:
* Plan on **“exploring”** the product at the beginning of each new sprint.
* Plan and build your scripts to perform automated functional and regression testing within the sprint (Because there is not enough time for performing thorough manual testing).
* Use the sprint backlog as your own test plan (or writing a test case or script for every feature)
* Some teams are treating test case scenarios as entries that need to be added to the sprint backlog for planning and tracking purposes
* Understand, remember, and process details.(Take notes!!!!)
* Transparency: Provide traceability among tests, features, and bugs and report my testing progress
* Acceptance Test Log of the exploratory test run (brief)
* Send a daily status email (brief)
